articles.headline: Fed Makes Biggest Interest Rate Increase Since 2000 as High Inflation Persists
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is combating the fastest price increases in four decades and is trying to cool the economy before high inflation becomes embedded.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is combating the fastest price increases in four decades and is trying to cool the economy before high inflation becomes embedded.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve ramped up its attack on rapid inflation on Wednesday, approving its biggest interest rate increase since 2000, detailing a plan to shrink its massive bond holdings and signaling that it will continue working to cool the economy as it tries to tamp down the fastest price increases in four decades.

articles.headline: As Victory Day Looms in Russia, Guesswork Grows Over Putin’s Ukraine Goals
articles.snippet: The Russian holiday celebrating the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany is viewed by Ukraine and NATO as a stage for the Russian president to proclaim a turn in the war.
articles.abstract: The Russian holiday celebrating the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany is viewed by Ukraine and NATO as a stage for the Russian president to proclaim a turn in the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the Russian military still struggling, Western officials and Ukraine’s traumatized residents are looking with increased alarm to Russia’s Victory Day holiday on May 9 — a celebration of the Soviet triumph over Nazi Germany — fearing that President Vladimir V. Putin may exploit it as a grandiose stage to intensify attacks and mobilize his citizenry for all-out war.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Corporate America Doesn’t Want to Talk Abortion, but It May Have To
articles.snippet: In a deeply divided nation, public statements on Roe v. Wade can affect everything from recruiting to a company’s bottom line. So far, that has kept almost everyone quiet.
articles.abstract: In a deeply divided nation, public statements on Roe v. Wade can affect everything from recruiting to a company’s bottom line. So far, that has kept almost everyone quiet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some political and cultural events set off a cascade of emails from brands — sneaker, makeup and food companies telling their customers that they stand with them in a stressful time, or reminding them to vote. But after a draft opinion obtained by Politico revealed the Supreme Court’s intention to overturn Roe v. Wade, the overwhelming reaction from corporate leaders was silence.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg, Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Once Close Allies, Roberts and Alito Have Taken Divergent Paths
articles.snippet: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. have become emblems of a stark divide at the Supreme Court as it confronts whether to overturn Roe v. Wade.
articles.abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. have become emblems of a stark divide at the Supreme Court as it confronts whether to overturn Roe v. Wade.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was a time when Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., the author of the leaked draft opinion on abortion that rocked the nation on Monday night, was Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s closest ally on the Supreme Court.

articles.headline: U.S. Intelligence Is Helping Ukraine Kill Russian Generals, Officials Say
articles.snippet: Targeting assistance is part of a classified effort by the Biden administration to provide real-time battlefield intelligence to Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Targeting assistance is part of a classified effort by the Biden administration to provide real-time battlefield intelligence to Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has provided intelligence about Russian units that has allowed Ukrainians to target and kill many of the Russian generals who have died in action in the Ukraine war, according to senior American officials.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: ‘I Can’t Have This Baby’: A Lone Abortion Clinic on the Border
articles.snippet: In the Rio Grande Valley, women seeking abortions navigate the complex challenges of religion, culture and a new Texas law.
articles.abstract: In the Rio Grande Valley, women seeking abortions navigate the complex challenges of religion, culture and a new Texas law.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Texas — The colorful murals outside the storefront clinic a few miles from the Mexican border celebrated “dignity, empowerment, compassion, justice.” Inside, there was a reminder posted on the wall for anyone who had begun to doubt it: “Abortion Is Legal in Texas!”

articles.headline: ‘Burning Down a Way of Life’: Wildfire Rips Through a Hispanic Bastion
articles.snippet: One of the largest wildfires in New Mexico’s history is raging through a region where the culture stretches back longer than the United States has existed.
articles.abstract: One of the largest wildfires in New Mexico’s history is raging through a region where the culture stretches back longer than the United States has existed.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS, N.M. — As rushing flames neared the remote mountains where his family has lived for generations, Miguel Martinez knew he had to move fast and flee with only the clothes on his back.

articles.headline: ‘I’m Very Anxious’: China’s Lockdowns Leave Millions Out of Work
articles.snippet: Migrant workers and recent college graduates have been hit hardest by shuttered factories, closed construction sites and an anemic job market.
articles.abstract: Migrant workers and recent college graduates have been hit hardest by shuttered factories, closed construction sites and an anemic job market.
articles.lead_paragraph: After over a month in lockdown, Zeng Jialin could finally return to the Shanghai auto parts factory where he had worked. He was about to be released from an isolation facility, having recovered from Covid-19, and was desperate to make up for the many days of wages he had missed.

articles.headline: Germany’s Military Industry Gears Up to Restock Its Own Forces
articles.snippet: The country’s chancellor has pledged about $100 billion to rebuild its army, but that increase in spending may not be enough to reverse years of neglect, experts say.
articles.abstract: The country’s chancellor has pledged about $100 billion to rebuild its army, but that increase in spending may not be enough to reverse years of neglect, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortages of body armor. Radios so antiquated they are the butt of jokes from other NATO soldiers. A dysfunctional procurement system that takes years just to acquire  shoulder patches.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Elon Musk has brought in new investors to fund his Twitter deal, a filing shows.
articles.snippet: The filing lists a number of investment firms and other backers who will contribute $7 billion to the deal.
articles.abstract: The filing lists a number of investment firms and other backers who will contribute $7 billion to the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: In numerous conversations over the last several days, Elon Musk began making promises about what he could do with Twitter.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch, Anupreeta Das, Erin Griffith and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Elon Musk Hates Ads. Twitter Needs Them. That May Be a Problem.
articles.snippet: Many marketers were already lukewarm on the service. Now, some may move their money elsewhere if the content moderation policies are relaxed.
articles.abstract: Many marketers were already lukewarm on the service. Now, some may move their money elsewhere if the content moderation policies are relaxed.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I hate advertising,” Elon Musk tweeted in 2019.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Stocks slide, erasing Wednesday’s big gains, as volatility continues to reign.
articles.snippet: Swings in the stock market have become amplified lately, as investors worry that inflation and fast-rising interest rates could hit spending, profits and — ultimately — economic growth.
articles.abstract: Swings in the stock market have become amplified lately, as investors worry that inflation and fast-rising interest rates could hit spending, profits and — ultimately — economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks dove on Thursday, erasing gains from their best day since 2020 in a swing that highlights Wall Street’s heightened anxiety over what the Federal Reserve’s campaign to slow inflation will mean for the economy.
